text: Canada has numerous Indian reserves for its First Nations people, which were mostly established by the Indian Act of 1876 and have been variously expanded and reduced by royal commissions since. Hay River Dene 1 and Salt River 195, shown by INAC. All other places listed here are called Indian Settlements. Not included are Norman Wells and Enterprise both of which have a significant First Nations population. Also not included are the Inuvialuit communities of Paulatuk (Siglit), Sachs Harbour (Siglit), Tuktoyaktuk (Siglit) and Ulukhaktok (Copper Inuit). == Nunavut == Nunavut does not have a significant First Nations (0.34%), Métis (0.44%), or non-Aboriginal (15.04%) populationNunavut Aboriginal profile from the 2006 census and has no reserves. All communities in the territory have a majority of Inuit residents and a breakdown can be seen at list of communities in Nunavut. == Ontario == {| class="wikitable sortable" 2" style="border-style:solid; border-width:1px; border-color:#fff; cellspacing=; width:100%;" |- style="background:#fff;" ! The Minister of Indian Affairs assigns 34 tracts of land as Indian reserves and settlements under the Indian Act: *Akwesasne 15 *Betsiamites *Cacouna 22 *Communauté Atikamekw de Manawan *Communauté de Wemotaci *Coucoucache 24A *Doncaster 17 *Eagle Village First Nation - Kipawa *Gesgapegiag *Grand Lac Victoria Indian Settlement *Innue Essipit *Kahnawake 14 *Kanesatake Lands *Kitigan Zibi *Lac John *Lac-Simon *Listuguj *Maliotenam 27A *Mashteuiatsh *Matimekosh 3 *Mingan *Natashquan 1 *Obedjiwan 28 *Odanak 12 *Pikogan *Rapid Lake *Romaine 2 *St- Augustin Indian Settlement *Timiskaming *Uashat 27 *Village des Hurons Wendake 7 *Whitworth 21 *Winneway Indian Settlement *Wôlinak 11 The Wolf Lake First Nation (Algonquin) and the Gespeg First Nation (Mi'kmaq) are two communities without any assigned reserve but recognized as Status Indian under the Indian Act. The First Nations and the Inuit in northern Quebec are covered by different laws based on the James Bay And Northern Quebec Agreement and the Northeastern Quebec Agreement, which superseded the Indian Act in the 1970s. No Indian reserve exists in northern Quebec, but Aboriginal peoples still live in specific villages with recognized rights: *Akulivik (Inuit) *Aupaluk (Inuit) *Chisasibi (Cree) *Eastmain (Cree) *Inukjuak (Inuit) *Ivujivik (Inuit) *Kangiqsualujjuaq (Inuit) *Kangiqsujuaq (Inuit) *Kangirsuk (Inuit) *Kawawachikamach (Naskapi) *Kuujjuaq (Inuit) *Kuujjuarapik (Inuit) *Mistissini (Cree) *Nemaska (Cree) *Oujé-Bougoumou (Cree) *Puvirnituq/Povungnituk (Inuit) *Quaqtaq (Inuit) *Salluit (Inuit) *Tasiujaq (Inuit) *Umiujaq (Inuit) *Waskaganish (Cree) *Waswanipi (Cree) *Wemindji (Cree) *Whapmagoostui (Cree) == Saskatchewan == {| class="wikitable sortable" 2" style="border-style:solid; border-width:1px; border-color:#fff; cellspacing=; width:100%;" |- style="background:#fff;" !
